questions.question:
Question 2: Below is a diagram depicting the natural history of the disease. Which point marks the onset 
of symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Point C represents a point where signs and symptoms appear. Various points marked in the image represent the following: Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These 
changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs 
and symptoms. Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident. 202 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 190 
Sold by @itachibot In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.explanation:
Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of 
diagnosis (point C). Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of 
diagnosis. Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by 
reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful 
and/or permanent damage would have occurred. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of 
disease and the usual time of diagnosis. That is conditions with a long lead time. Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and 
the maximal infectivity of that host.

questions.question:
Question 4: In which of the following diseases, screening procedure increases the overall survival to the 
maximum?
questions.explanation:
Screening of colon cancer increases the overall survival to the maximum. Colon cancer has a long lead time and can be detected early before pathological changes occur. It 
can be curable if treated early, otherwise fatal in half the cases. Early diagnosis and treatment before the critical point have a good outcome and reduce the 
severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be 
unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred. Other diseases that can be screened are: • Cervical cancer 203 
Sold by @itachibot • Breast cancer • Prostate cancer

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

options.a: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
options.c: Pap smear in women above 40 years
options.d: Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.explanation:
Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening. Types of screening: • Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a 
large number of people at one time. Example- Annual health checkups. • High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example- MRI screening of breast 
done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative. • Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using a chest X-ray for TB 
screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.question: Question 8: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

options.b: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
options.d: Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.explanation:
When a large number of tests are done in series, net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is 
increased. Screening tests are done in series when the result of the first test determines whether to run the 
second test or not. e.g., HIV screening is done using consecutive ELISA. Screening tests are done in parallel when the second test is independently performed regardless of 
what the first test result is. Both the tests are done at the same time. ’or e.g., In L’T, multiple

questions.question:
Question 10: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by a 
new screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of a 
new screening test being described?
questions.explanation:
The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the same 
conditions is called reliability. Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

questions.question:
Question 11: Ten successive readings of hemoglobin level of a single sample measured by a new method 
are given below. The hemoglobin level measured by the previous standard test was 10.2. 
What is true regarding the new method?
questions.explanation:
The new method for measuring hemoglobin has high validity and low reliability. The new test doesn’t give the same values on repeat testing, thus it has low reliability. The mean 
value of all the readings is 10. The mean is close to the value of 10.2, which is obtained from the 
standard test, making the validity high. The validity of a test implies that the test must give correct and accurate results. It represents the 
closeness to a true/ actual value. The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the 
same individual or material, under the same conditions.

questions.question: Question 16: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect:
questions.explanation:
Specificity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who do not have 
the disease, i.e. true negative. Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the 
disease, i.e. true positive. ’alse-positive are those who don't have the disease but tested positive. ’alse-negative are those who have the disease but tested negative.

questions.question:
Question 18: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her 
actually having the disease?
questions.explanation:
Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having 
the disease. It is the ability of a test to detect true positive(TP) out of total positive(TP+’P) and it is directly 
proportional to the prevalence of a disease. PPV= TP/TP+’P

questions.question:
Question 19: To calculate the positive predictive value of a new screening test for breast carcinoma, what 
will you use for the denominator?
questions.explanation:
The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is true 
positives + false positives. Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + ’P) x 100. It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directly 
proportional to the prevalence of a disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected the 
most by prevalence.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following maximally affect the positive predictive value of a test?
questions.explanation:
Positive predictive value (PPV) is maximally affected by the prevalence of the disease. If the prevalence of a disease in a population is high, the high will be the positive predictive value 
of a screening test, and the more accurate will be the test. If the prevalence declines, the PPV will 
be low. PPV is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. It is affected the most by prevalence. 
However, both sensitivity and specificity can change the predictive value.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following reflects the diagnostic power of a screening test?
questions.explanation:
209 
Sold by @itachibot The predictive accuracy of a screening test reflects its performance and diagnostic power. Predictive accuracy is given by: • Positive predictive value (PPV): the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having 
the disease. • Negative predictive value (NPV): the probability of a person with a negative test, definitely not 
having the disease. Sensitivity is the ability of a screening test to detect true positive out of total disease. Specificity is the ability of a screening test to detect true negative out of total nondiseased. The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the 
same individual or material, under the same conditions.

questions.question:
Question 22: Screening of 100 immigrants for COVID-1‘ with a new test showed 48 positive and 52 people 
negative. Those who tested negative underwent RTPCR out of which 25 came positive. Which 
of the following is lowest for the new test compared to RTPCR?
questions.explanation:
The sensitivity of the new screening test is low compared to RTPCR. The new screening test showed 52 people negative, out of which 25 are detected positive by 
RTPCR. i.e. 25 are false negative. The false-negative rate is the number of false-negative out of total people having the disease. ’alse-negative rate = 1 - Sensitivity The false-negative rate increases as sensitivity decreases. In this scenario, because the new test has more false negatives, it would have low sensitivity as 
compared to RTPCR.

questions.question:
Question 26: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of a disease in a community has been 
reduced by ‘0%. However, the physicians continue to use the same screening test for that 
disease. Which of the following changes is expected to be seen?
questions.explanation:
If the prevalence of the disease falls, the negative predictive value(NPV) increases. The NPV of the test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease. The PPV of the test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease. Sensitivity and specificity are independent of the prevalence of the disease in the area. They do 
not change with the change in prevalence.

questions.question: Question 29: Which of the following is best for determining the threshold for diagnosis of a positive test?
questions.explanation:
The receiver operator characteristic curve is the best for determining the threshold for the 
diagnosis of a positive test. It is also used for the comparison of two or more screening/ diagnostic 
tests of disease with each other. The following is an example of a ROC curve for a screening test. 213 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 30: Which curve from the given image reflects a better test? 198 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Test A is the best test among the four given, as it has the highest sensitivity and the lowest false 
positive rate (100-specificity). A receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC) is obtained by plotting a test's true positive rate 
(sensitivity) against its false-positive rate ( 100- specificity) for different diagnostic cut-off points. The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test, the more it moves to the 
upper left (more the area under the curve). ’or a good test, sensitivity comes close to 100% on the 
y-axis, and the false positive rate comes close to 0% on the x-axis.
